content.value: How do you ensure critical applications are available to users when they need them? Let's imagine you work online and use cloud-based software to complete your daily tasks, attend team meetings over Zoom, and also want to chat with your mates on messenger, watch tutorials on youtube, and so on.

In network management, these applications fall into categories of priority ranging from critical to insignificant. To ensure you and your team can continue to work when the network is under load, business-critical apps need to be prioritized over other traffic. This project aims to translate these requirements into a simplified UI that allows administrators to easily define rule sets and deploy them at scale.

duration.en-US: 3 months - 1 release cycle with further updates completed in later release as result of feedback & testing.

role.en-US:
User research, 
UI design, 
Prototyping, 
Usability testing.
Front end development.

content.value: User Interviews

Application Priority is intended to be used alongside other traffic control features. Feedback from clients there is confusion around the output and role of class percentages, and how they affect other features in Vista Manager. I set up a series of user interviews to better understand the problem and confirm our current assumptions about the issue.

Test participants were selected to represent expert and intermediate levels. Only admins are able to create policies, non-admin read-write users with permissions can view both policies and ATS settings so they must also be able to understand the UI.
Goals:
Identify causes of confusion in the current Application Priority UI.
Clarify the intended use of guaranteed minimum bandwidth values in policies.
Clarify policy behavior when used alongside ATS.
Improve workflow for creating and applying policies.
Improve workflow for applying ATS with Application Priority policies.
Results:

All participants interviewed assumed that class percentage values should be dividing up  100% of the bandwidth available and did not realize that these values actually translate to CIR values (expert users did realize this after viewing generated config ). 

This was a problem. If we guarantee 100% of the bandwidth traffic default traffic will be dropped as soon as the network comes under load. The cause of this was the default values provided to the sliders for each class. Test participants assumed they should just max out sliders to get the best result. We needed to first provide a healthy default and second indicate to the user that space should be left over for other traffic/features.
Recommendations:
Display default traffic class to indicate remaining traffic Mbps
Provide appropriate labeling to describe classes and class priority roles.
Adjust default slider values to represent realistic config
Combine sliders into a multi-range slider, each dividing the bandwidth among four application classes (including Other and System?)
Place CIR config in the deploy step where Max Tx is available to calculate CIR in Mbps.
Provide reasonable default values and allow users to edit if required.
Indicate no more than 40% of link capacity should be guaranteed.
What went well

Feedback was coming in from the field post-release so we knew the feature was in use. This is not always the case so it was reassuring to receive a request for a second phase of development. The majority of changes required were informational and not technical to change.

Phase 2 user Interviews really highlighted the importance of fitting a dedicated testing phase into projects. Testers embedded in teams are often too close to the project to pick up on key usability issues.

External testers were impressed by the simplicity and speed at that they could deploy traffic control compared with the CLI. Saving config as a reusable policy stored in software reduces the time required to configure Traffic control across the network.
What we could have done better:

Configuration MUST be assigned to a specific interface on a device. 
This meant a degree of repetition that could not be avoided in the configuration process. Work would need to be done to allow the system to automate deployment decisions. 

Going further, we would need to push to develop a group-based system to deploy policy on devices with matching capabilities. A policy can be deployed directly to the device group to further reduce repetition. We can then think of configuration in human terms for example:
{Prioritise} {zoom traffic} between {branch offices} during {work hours}. This approach allows for a single touch point where previously you would be handling hundreds oif not thousands.

Even further down the track, if the system is smart enough to remember the administrator's decision-making, the system can apply the same rules when common events or conditions occur in the network, In networking jargon, this is referred to as zero-touch or a self-managing network.  Read more at
https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc9315.html

content.value: In a network, Access control lists (ACLs) are used to restrict or allow traffic based on various factors such as source IP address, destination IP address, protocol type, port number, and other criteria. They are essentially a set of rules that define what types of traffic or users are allowed to access a particular resource. For example, an ACL might be configured to allow traffic from a specific IP address range to access a particular network resource, while blocking traffic from all other sources.

ACLs can be implemented on various network devices, such as routers, switches, and firewalls, and are an important component of network security. They help to prevent unauthorized access and ensure that only authorized users and devices are able to access network resources.

role.en-US:
Driving mapping sessions, isualize feedback from Eng departments.
Lofi wireframing sessions with PO and team
Hifo Wireframes & Prototypes

content.value: Discovery

As a team, we held a series of discovery meetings with stakeholders and experts to help define what was technically possible and what was expected as an MVP. 

We were asked to develop an intent-based system to create and deploy ACLs within Vista Manager. In an intent-based networking (IBN) system, access control lists (ACLs) can be configured using policies that are defined at a higher level of abstraction than in traditional CLI-based networks. The goal of intent-based networking is to make network management more intuitive and automated, reducing the need for manual configuration and troubleshooting.
Requirements:
Define ACL rules as a policy

Allowing the user to define rules once and apply them at multiple touchpoints reduces repetition. GUIs can simplify the process of configuring ACLs by reducing the complexity of the configuration process, and presenting the user with simple and intuitive interfaces for defining the rules.
Deploy ACL Policy at scale

Applying ACLs to a grouping of devices can improve the manageability, scalability, and consistency of access control in a network, making it easier to ensure that security requirements are met and that network performance is optimized.
Visualize ACL configuration in the network

By visualizing ACL configurations, network administrators can better understand how access control is enforced in the network. This can help them identify potential security risks and ensure that access control is applied correctly.
Automate the assignment of ALCs to network users

Automating the assignment of ACLs to network users ensures consistent and accurate access control policies are enforced, and reduces repetition by eliminating the need for manual configuration of ACLs for each individual user, device, or application.
Expert Interviews
Configuring access control lists (ACLs) in a command-line interface (CLI) environment can be challenging and time-consuming.
To get an idea of how complex this is have a read of this.
I interviewed members of the test and validation teams to gain an understanding of how ACLs are configured on the command line interface.
Some of the pain points associated with this process include:
Complexity:

ACLs can be very complex, with a large number of rules and criteria that need to be specified. This can make it difficult to ensure that the ACLs are correctly configured and to troubleshoot issues that arise.
Limited visibility:

In a CLI environment, it can be difficult to get a clear picture of the current ACL configuration or to identify which rules are causing problems. This can make it harder to manage ACLs and ensure that they are functioning correctly.
Time-consuming:
Configuring ACLs in a CLI environment is a time-consuming process that requires a lot of manual input. This can be especially challenging in large networks with complex ACL requirements.
Error-prone:

Configuring ACLs in a CLI environment can be prone to errors, particularly when there are multiple administrators or if the administrator is not experienced or familiar with the syntax and commands involved. It is These errors can lead to security breaches or other issues with network performance.
Lack of automation:

In a CLI environment, ACL configuration is typically a manual process that requires a lot of repetitive tasks. This lack of automation can make it difficult to scale ACL configuration or to make changes quickly in response to changing network requirements.
mapping

subtitle.en-US: How do you manage & deploy OS upgrade to hundreds of devices with minimal downtime?

content.value: How do you manage & deploy OS upgrade to
hundreds

of devices with minimal downtime?

For an example lets use a server farm.
In the server farm you have many different models of device ranging in age and OS version.
Your boss requests that all machines are to be running the latest OS, and make sure none of the clients are effected by device downtime when you reboot the machines.
How would you go about this task? 
 
You might send a guy/girl out to the site to manually update each device, but hey you've got multiple sites, even with remote access this is looking like significant hours and a significant bill to do the job. Then lets get into the problems.. Is the OS image stored on the device or on an external drive? does the drive have sufficient disk space to hold the new OS? When can the device be rebooted? You can see this is getting out of hand, so how can we make this simple?

This is the problem the project aims to solve.
To d this we will 
Visibility of system status : Identify What OS are all devices running  identify old releases.
Ease of configuration: Bulk deployment of OS to devices, Scheduling of reboot.
Error handling on the fly : Notify when device storage is maxed out and continue.

duration.en-US: 2 months - 1 release cycle with further updates completed in later release as result of feedback from users

role.en-US: User research, UI design, Prototyping, Usability testing. Front end development.

content.value:
At Allied Telesis we hold monthly training sessions for GUI teams focused on coding best practices and in-depth tutorials for some of the more unknown areas of the codebase. One of the areas developers were not so familiar with was our angular component library, a set of UI components that are used frequently throughout the application. 

I was asked to host a training session to share knowledge of the shared component libraries (Figma & Angular) with teams. Content would cover best practices for using global variables, interpretation of Figma documents for developer handoff, and guidelines for creating and maintaining components.

role.en-US:
Content development and hosting of training session

I think the biggest thing people struggle with is deciding when to make a piece of UI a component so we set out some guidelines for this...

We wanted there to be an estabelished set of patters for using and building components
e.g forms Walked though an example of how we can make a generic component that covers multiple use cases and how that can be extended in the feature components to provide the unique properties we need.

content.value: Developers weren't using the UI component library.

A select few had been involved in the creation of the UI component library and were doing a good job of sharing the knowledge within teams but we found that in general developers were resorting to copying legacy template code or creating new components.  We wanted to make sure that developers are aware of all components in the library, when it was appropriate to use components, and what tricks you could use to avoid adding unnecessary template code.
Developers weren't making the most of Figma documents
Questions were often raised about which components to use in development.

As a designer, I knew that the components used in Figma were directly related to those in the angular library. I had given some short team tutorials in the past but when I asked around I found that developers were only ever reading the document notes, and developers vary rarely dived into the layers panel to understand component and layout values. So some basic training was needed to share how to interact with Figma documents.

I felt that giving developers the power to use Figma was a better approach than using another handoff tool because A. understanding design software is a valuable skill to have as a developer and B. people in the company are hesitant to introduce new apps to the growing stack, especially management (who often prefer static PDFs) so if we could build on the traction we already had with Figma we were on the right track.

content.en-US: All participants interviewed assumed that guaranteed bandwidth values for each class should be adding up to 100% of available bandwidth.

content.value: Component Principles (Draft)
* No feature logic in shared components.
Components accept basic input only.
Use form control for form inputs?
Follow naming conventions for input/output controls.
Include test IDs & unit tests.
When to make a component shared?
Whenever a design doc specifies a shared component.
Whenever a feature component is likely to be commonly used.
Notify development teams that a new component is available.
When to avoid making a component shared?
* When the component must contain logic specific to a feature.
Consider if this component is adding complexity to devs life.

Consider if the component contains elements that should remain
separate for simplicity. E.g footer actions.
strong text*h2. *Find and update a component in shared dir to meet naming conventions.

Some components in the library do not use the prefix app-.
This prefix is used to identify components as shared or generic app wide components.
Find and update a component that does not meet this convention.
Move a component into the shared directory

We have many components that could be considered for the component library.
For example older components can be found under vista-app > components & vista-app > shared > components.
Find a component you think is worthy of moving into the library.
Remember to follow naming conventions.
Improve existing components

Make an improvement to individual component or component pattern.
For example:
Remove functions that should become feature logic.
Add helpful input options to extend existing components.
Add form controls to form components.
Fix any lint errors
Organize common input enums
Ensure inputs follow naming conventions
Ensure test IDs are avaialble
Replace and remove redundant components (or template code)

Identify components or template syntax that can be replaced by a library component.
This includes those within the library.
For example:
Replacing components
For example app-typeahead-select can potentially be merged into app-select by providing a allowSearch function within app-select, both use ng-select.
Find and replace components that can be merged or replaced by lib components.
Consider removing single use components if they can be replaced with lib components.
Consider removing component that contain feature specific references.
Replacing syntax

Got to styles > components, font a component class e.g. c-message
Replace all instances with the <app-message> component.
Once all are replaced the styles can be moved into the component.
Replace variables in vista.

All variables (scss & js) should make use of tokens wherever possible to maintain design.
For example:
Find and replace css variables with token variables.
Find and replace #hex code colors used in css and .ts files.

Now that we had component names matching we gave an overview of the components and the roles that they serve in the app. We explained how component variants in Figma are also named to match Angular component inputs that describe the component's state. Every option we have to control the style of a component is also available in the angular version.
Getting in sync: Variables
A few years back I decided to start managing variables using
Style Dictionary

in Angular with the hope that we could serve a single set of style variables to teams based in NZ and Japan. Style dictionary allows us to import variables into multiple projects (including our growing component library) as an npm package.

With the latest release, we can now manage tokens(variables) in Figma. Token updates are pushed from Figma to the npm package, all we need to do is update the package version in package.js and we're good to go. Design changes are rolled out with a single line of code.
Getting In sync : Components

We knew that devs were having a hard time making the connection between Figma and Angular components. To improve the handoff process we updated component names in Figma to match 1:1 with those in Angular e.g. app-my-component-name.  This helps us to separate components in the library from feature components. While making the updates we also completed an audit general of components in Figma and Angular, taking note of duplicates and redundancies.

I sat down with testers and validation team members as proxy users...
Firmware upgrades had traditionally been completed manually by a skilled technician. 
Each release upgrade would need to be applied device by device via remote connection or onsite if firmware was applied on the flash drive. This is an extremely time consuming and hight cost process. For example to upgrade devices in a national network the network manager would be required to sink many (expensive) hours logging into each device and applying the sam config over and over again. A tedious process.
AMF areas

Larger networks are split into AMF areas.
Each are will have it own manager, network design and licensing.
Upgrades may need to be applied at different time across areas.
Files must be deployed via the AMF master (per area) device for distribution.
Deployment Errors

We cant guarantee deployment will be successful for n reasons.
A pre-check system will be required to inform users of failures as they occur.
A system to highlight out of date firmware version in UI is required to identify an resolve.
Reboot

Devices must be rebooted to be run the new release.
Devices cannot be down during work hours so a scheduled reboot system is required.
As a team we held a series of discovery meetings with stakeholders and experts to define a clear idea of what was technically possible and what was expected as a MVP.

---------------------- TBC

There was an existing  API for distribution of firmware from the master/controller.
Providing access to an online repo was a nice to have, for this release users must pre download any real files from the resource centre and select file from local hard drive.
Select multiple devices for firmware update
Allow upload of firmware to Vista Manager
Upload firmware to devices
Schedule reboot of update

We provided upgrades per device family, some devices may fail. 
Sone major clients were hospitals using monitoring devices, these devices must be running at all times. Any downtime could be deadly. These devices need to be omitted from the upgrade process.  To solve this we provided individual device selections within families.

This raises another issue with the AMF area system. Ideally critical devices would be protected by hiding them from the process altogether. A groups based approach may be better solution long term this would allow the app to auto define groups of devices by family,
location and users can create sub groups to protect critical devices.
Think long term

This raises another issue with the AMF area system. Ideally critical devices would be protected by hiding them from the process altogether. A groups based approach may be better solution long term this would allow the app to auto define groups of devices by family, location and users can create sub groups to protect critical devices.
Depending on the dize and diversity of our users We might want to create several tiers of priority to catch and categorise traffic as it moves through the network.

OUr to tier get first dibs
OUr 2nd teir gets a chunk of the remaining if the top tier dednt required
and anything else can fight over the left overs. 
(Idealy it should be blocked all together at entry to the network via ablack list...)

How do you define user access to parts of your network at scale?

Imagine you are in charge of managing access for all departments of a large company.
This means you need grant give basic internet access to most users, you also want to prevent these user from accessing sensitive documents and directories within you system, while allowing access to management staff. 

Imagine you have a school. Teachers, cleaning staff, security, students from new entrants to seniors, and each of these groups require different levels of access.
Potentially this system needs to cover everything FOB door access to browsing the web. Including what applications are accessible and when.

How do you visualise and manage secure access to
all

of your users?
The dark days asasas

You need to keep track of whos who so that access is not granted when it shouldnt ect ect.
And nobody is unecesarilly locked out of the system.
...
Ease of configuration : You need a way to manage users and endpoint devices how can they be grouped?

I sat down with members of the test and validation teams to have them walk me through the process of applying Traffic Control in the current environment to identify any standard workflows and any pain points.
Who is using this feature?
This feature is traditionally limited to senior administrators. This is expensive from a business viewpoint, simplifying the configuration process allows lower-level staff to maintain the network.
Repeated tasks

Admins are required to manually apply config on a device per device basis.
The process was time consuming and repetitive. Often used simple methods to speed this up: e.g Copy and paste in notepad or noting repeated config down on paper.
Advanced feature set

Configuration can get very granular however advanced configuration is not required for most network wide scenarios. Configuration is also difficult to interpret as text in CLI.
This meant a simplified feature set could be exposed to Users. Users do not need to be concerned with low-level device configuration and nerd knobs.
How does this feature work with others ?

As TC is applied to a interface (RX/TX?) this feature is not intended to be used in unison with SD-WAN application rules (these rules load balance traffic between multiple links). We will need to warn users if interfaces are members of SD-WAN rules.
Gotchas
Several issues came up that would mean we needed to pull back expectations for the forst release. Focus on providing policy for later use in a bulk deployment sytems

There were some limitations  that would need to be addresed in later releases.... Configuration MUST be assigned to entities (API requirment) that reference the interface or link the user intends apps to be controlled. This means deployment is limited to single devices for this release. Ideally we would want to support a grouping system using a range of parameters to have the ability to apply config network widt in a single deplyment,.
Discovery

As a team, we held a series of discovery meetings with stakeholders and experts to define a clear idea of what was technically possible and what was expected as an MVP. For this release of Vista Manager, we were asked to develop tools to visualize application use in the network and provide a system to prioritize application traffic as it flows through the network.

We found that there were several CLI-based features to prioritize application traffic, each with a unique approach. For our requirements "Traffic control" gave us the best solution to ensure business-critical traffic was flowing as expected in the network. As a bonus existing APIs meant work could start immediately.
Read more about Traffic Control here
Requirements:
Visualize traffic makeup on network devices for analysis.
Select and categorize apps into priority classes.
Save the configuration as a policy for bulk deployment
Deploy policies to devices.
Expert Interviews

I sat down with members of the test and validation teams, these guys manage test networks within the company.  I had them walk through the process of applying Traffic Control via the CLI to identify any standard workflows and any pain points.
Who is using this feature?

This feature is traditionally limited to senior administrators.  Simplifyingstreamlining the configuration and deployment process will allow lower-level staff to maintain the network. Read-only users will also need to have access to any monitoring tools provided.
Repeated tasks

Admins are required to manually apply config on a device-per-device basis.
The process was time-consuming and repetitive. Users often used simple methods to speed this up: e.g Copying and pasting in notepad or noting repeated config down on paper.
Advanced feature set

Configuration can get very granular with sub-polices and sub-classes, however, advanced configuration is generally not required for most network-wide scenarios. This means a simplified feature set can be exposed to Users.
Gotchas

Configuration must be assigned to an interface (a limitation of traffic control). This means deployment must happen on a device-per-device basis. Ideally, we would group devices by type or capability and have the system select the interface, this would allow network-wide configuration in a single deployment.

content.en-US: Ideally your system has the ability to learn from previous decisions and apply the same rules when devices move or now ones join the network, resulting in a zero touch self managing system. In out case this would be a wee way off into the future.

subtitle.en-US: Server and Client DPI Application Sharing

content.value: In networking when we talk about applications, we are really talking about the classification of traffic. This is achieved by identifying traffic by a protocol such as HTTP, HTTPS, FTP, or the more advanced
Deep packet inspection(DPI)

method. DPI allows for more fine-grained identification. For example, we can also detect traffic coming from specific websites and cloud applications and treat it according to on our network policy.  This might mean blocking it entirely, limiting bandwidth, or prioritizing it over all other traffic. Licensed Application libraries like
Procera

classify thousands of applications and are widely used in the networking industry. 

In short,  this feature is like a shared Netflix account for traffic on network devices.
Router devices can share access to multiple application libraries in order to identify and treat traffic as it flows through the network. Now Features required to reference applications like
traffic control
and traffic shaping can be configured using a common policy set across the network. This approach is critical in allowing network admins to configure and monitor network devices at scale.

role.en-US: UI design, Prototyping, Usability testing. Front end development.

content.en-US: "Managing networks by configuring myriads of "nerd knobs" on a device-by-device basis is no longer an option in modern network environments."

content.value: What is Intent?

Intent based networking provides functional abstraction from particular management and control logic: Users do not need to be concerned even with how to achieve a given intent. What is specified is the desired outcome with the IBS automatically figuring out a course of action (e.g., using an algorithm or applying a set of rules derived from the intent) for how to achieve the outcome.

You can see example of intent everywhere nowdays in our apps, audio example

IMG

In networking managing intent this boils down to having the power to group common elements of your network. Organising infrastructure or user devices into logical groups that will share a set of rules within the network. Once you have your devices grouped you can also organise common chunks of configuration or events into 'policies' which can be applied to groups. 

We can then think of configuration in human terms for example:
{Prioritise} {zoom traffic} between {branch offices} during {work hours}.
This approach allows for a single touch point where previously you would be handling hundreds.

IMG

Even further down the track, if you are smart enough to  remember you decision making data, the system can have ability to learn from previous decisions, under the watch of an human, and apply the same rules when common events occur in the network, In networking jargon this is is referred to as zero-touch or a self managing network.
Like skynet by cyberdyne systems :)

But for us that was a few years away.
For this project we were focused on defining policy. High level rules that can be applied to multiple devices within the network.

As a team, we held discovery meetings with stakeholders and experts to define a clear idea of what was technically possible and what was expected as an MVP. 

For this release, we were asked to develop tools that allow users to configure application libraries within Vista Manager and share that configuration between router devices in the network. Applications

Advanced application libraries like Procera are licensed on a device basis, however, it is possible to import classification from one device to another. This sounded a lot like copying a license key. Initially, we thought this sounded suss, so we checked with management and were ensured that the sharing system was legally above board and had been given the thumbs up from the provider DPI).
Basic Requirements:
View Supported Applications (Custom, DPI, Vista)
Prioritize the classification of custom applications if required
Enable application sharing on supported server devices.
Connect client devices to the server
Applications
In Vista Manager applications are organized into 3 prioritized groups:
Custom:
Provieds Priority --- User-defined applications stored in Vista Manager. Traffic will be matched against these rules first and take priority...
DPI: Provides acuracy --
A Third party library running on licensed devices only. DPI applications take priority over Built-in applications.
Built-in: Provides wide scope --

Around 100 Default applications that come baked-in to devices. These are your standard protocols HTTP, HTTPS, FTP... 


To support existing configuration (before DPI) the user must be able to "promote" built-in apps to custom/user-defined, this would allow for current policy to operate as per usual and provide a mixture of narrow and wide scope across application categories when required. In most cases, users would be using DPI or Built-In only.

Lo-fi Miro wireframes were developed during initial team discussions. Initially, the team had suggested using a drag-and-drop to move applications from built-in to custom, however this would become troublesome when moving apps from a scrolled position outside of the viewport. To solve this issue we made use of AG-grid custom row feature to separate application groups.

DPI applications (in the 1000s) could also be hidden in order to save valuable screen space. 
The aim of the page is to provide a system to prioritize built-in and custom apps over the DPI lib. aso At this point, it is not critical to expose individual apps in their 1000s here. In features that require selection, apps can are selected by category for ease of configuration and the entire library is documented online.

Traffic-related features are located in many places throughout the app including traffic monitoring features on the map and policy creation pages. 

Previously users would need to navigate back and forth to the applications page to enable and disable DPI , Warnings would need to be applied at all locations using DPI.

To improve the workflow we decided to provide DPI configuration via a widget that can be accessed anywhere in the app, this means full configuration visibility and control are available anywhere and any warnings need only be provided once.

Online Portfolio: 
behance.net/rikisommers

Contact:
rikisommers@yahoo.co.nz
0274486468

Kia Ora

I am passionate about designing
simple, intuitive, and beautiful experiences that improve peoples lives.

I've spent the last few years working as a UX/UI designer in an agile environment, focused on products in the computer networking industry.  Prior to my current position, I worked in agencies throughout Aotearoa, assisting in the creation of websites, apps, and marketing materials for a wide variety of industries.

In my current role, I have been involved in projects from the planning phase through to code completion. You might find me working with stakeholders to resolve feature requirements, developing wireframes and prototypes for teams, or gathering feedback to drive future development. Outside of project work, I have worked with GUI teams to develop Figma and Angular component libraries that are now used across 
multiple applications.

You can find examples of my work online at https://www.behance.net/rikisommersRecent case studies are available upon request.

Kia Ora

I am passionate about designing intuitive products that enable people to work smarter. 
I've spent the last few years working as a UX/UI designer in an agile environment, focused on products in the computer networking industry. 
Prior to my current position, I have worked in agencies throughout Aotearoa, assisting in the creation of websites, apps, and marketing materials for a variety of industries.

In my current role, I have been involved in projects from the planning phase through to code completion. You might find me working with stakeholders to resolve feature requirements, developing wireframes and prototypes for teams, or gathering feedback to drive future development. Outside of project work, I have worked with GUI teams to develop Figma and Angular component libraries that are now used across 
multiple applications.

You can find examples of my work online at https://www.behance.net/rikisommersRecent case studies are available upon request.

Online Portfolio: 
behance.net/rikisommers

Contact:
rikisommers@yahoo.co.nz
0274486468
sfsdfsdfsdf
Widget Requirements
I can view & edit DPI settings via the widget without navigating off-page.
I would like to protect my client's device from becoming a provider
I would like to know if I don't have applications because my server went down
I would like to protect devices from users without write permission

One of the biggest struggles for us with was deciding when or when not to make a piece of UI a component so we set out rough guidelines to start the discussion. I also wanted to make developers aware of the pitfalls of creating components with too narrow a scope. Often I would find 2-3 components with very similar behavior each with very specific input and output requirements. By removing the specificity we can make a single component do the job of all with a few minor tweaks.

We walked the teams through a couple of examples showing how we can make a generic component that covers multiple use cases and how a component can be extended to provide the unique properties we require.
Component Principles
No feature logic in shared components.
Components accept non-specific input types only (E.g string, number, any).
Always use form controls for form input values
Follow common naming conventions for input/output controls (e.g title, errorText).
Include test IDs & unit tests when required.
When to make a component shared
Whenever a design doc specifies a shared component.
Whenever a component is likely to be commonly used.
Notify development teams that a new component is available.
When to avoid making a component shared?
When the component must contain logic specific to a feature.
Consider if this component is adding unnecessary complexity to the developer's life.
Consider if the component can be separated for simplicity/reusability.

Lastly, we split up into 2-3 person teams to work on some real-life examples, this is where we get to test what we had learned during the day. Teams were given an hour to work on one of the suggested examples below. After the time was up we joined back up to review commits as a group. All in all, I was really happy with the result of the training session. From the code review sessions, I could see that the info had been absorbed, lots of questions were asked and developers were actively joining in on the discussion as we debated the benefits of each other's code. I could see that developers are actively thinking about component principles and independently spreading the knowledge within the teams. Success.

Task Examples:

Ensure all components meet naming conventions:

Some components in the library do not use the prefix app-. This prefix is used to identify components as shared or generic app-wide components. Find and update a component that does not meet this convention.
Move a component into the shared directory
We have many components that could be considered for the component library. For example. Find a component you think is worthy of moving into the library. Remember to follow naming conventions.
Improve existing components
Make an improvement to individual components or component patterns. For example:
Remove functions that should become feature logic.
Add input options to extend existing components.
Simplify components that use specific types in input/output
Add form controls to form components.
Organize common input enums
Ensure test IDs are available
Replace and remove redundant components (or template code).

Identify components or template syntax that can be replaced by a library component. This includes those within the library. For example, app-typeahead-select can potentially be merged into app-select by providing a simple search function within app-select, both use ng-select.
Find and replace components that can be merged or replaced by library components.
Consider removing single-use components if they can be replaced with library components.
Consider removing components that contain feature-specific references.

content.en-US: Often I would 2-3 components with similar behavior, each with very specific input and output requirements. By removing the specificity we can make a single component do the job of all with a few minor tweaks.

content.value: Filtering
This system does not consider devices with differing roles and types (e.g. Router vs Switch).
Events
Add support for thresholds per device type in health monitoring dashboard
Description

Network monitoring dashboard requires the ability to filter devices with similar hardware health expectations. Currently users are forced to apply global thresholds to all devices. This system does not consider devices with differing roles and types (e.g. Router vs Switch). Adding support for thresholds per device type or role will allow for more accurate monitoring and troubleshooting of network performance.

For Example:
Hardware health: CPU values will be expected to be much higher in routers using software to process and route packets.
Switches using hardware to process packets will be lower. It becomes difficult to precisely track device health.
Use cases:
I can apply thresholds to a sub selection of devices with similar health expectations
I can ignore non-critical devices contributing to network health state
Sugested Functionality:
Add ability to filter by device type, device name, group
Add ability to use filters to include or exclude
Add ability to save filter selection as dashboard view (see map layouts for example
https://jira.atlnz.lc/browse/MRS-787
Add ability to save dashboard view as primary dashboard (what you see when you first visit the page)
Add ability to apply thresholds per dashboard view
Considerations:

Note that this problem can also be solved by supporting thresholds per device or device type. This approach has its own issues where devices take on different roles in the network (e.g L2, L3, Core). The reason I have suggested applying thresholds per dashboard is purely for ease of configuration. Any custom thresholds could also affect state in the main dashboard.
Improvements to device grouping will provide support for targeting devices by type and role.
Value for the end-user

Allowing the user to filter the dashboard by device type is useful to avoid false negatives.
As thresholds are applied globally, devices with higher values will contribute to a negative state seen in the monitoring widgets as orange or red. Adding the ability to view & apply thresholds to a sub selection of devices with similar expectations allows users to precisely track network health and avoid false negatives.
Add support for health monitoring event rules
Description

This enhancement provides the ability to generate alerts(events + event rules) when health expectations are failing to be met. When device or path thresholds are exceeded, an event is triggered. Users can then create event rules to trigger actions when events are fired.
We currently support notification actions only. Support for action to run script is suggested in
https://jira.atlnz.lc/browse/MRS-323
Value for the end-user
Admin can be notified of critical events when they are away from the dashboard.
Admin can automate actions for health monitoring events.
Suggested Functionality:
Add ability to see events when health monitoring thresholds are exceeded.
Add ability to create event rules for health monitoring events.
Add ability to create event rules prior to event.
Examples:
Hardware Health: Event rules are configured to send email alerts to admin when hardware health thresholds are exceeded on critical hospital devices.
Traffic Health: Event Rules are configured to run script that redirects traffic when Traffic health thresholds are exceeded on key pathways.
Considerations:

Avoiding false negatives:
To avoid the potential of generating large numbers of unwanted events we would need to provide
a way to apply accurate thresholds to individual devices or device groups. This work has been suggested in
We might also want to disable or ignore events for non critical devices and pathways.

Creating Rules:
Currently event rules must be created from existing events,
In the examples provided, ideally we would want the ability to set up rules prior to an event being triggered.

Rule Actions:
Providing support to run custom scripts on devices would be a step towards an automated system.
Note that currently this would only possible on AW+ devices.

Alert delay times:
Polling times would mean event rules would fire at the next polling period.
This would be slower than using environmental alarms. Work can be done to improve this.

title.en-US: How does Application Priority affect other features?

content.value: Auto Traffic Shaping (ATS) and Application Priority are intended to be used together. Auto Traffic Shaping (ATS) allocates virtual bandwidth to spokes of multipoint tunnels based on a range of conditions. Bandwidth already guaranteed via Application Priority cannot be used by ATS.  We needed to update UI to expose guaranteed bandwidth values to users.

content.en-US: Testers were impressed by the simplicity and speed that they could deploy traffic control compared with the CLI.

content.value: Expert Interviews
The process of configuring access control lists (ACLs) in the CLI is notoriously challenging and time-consuming.
To get an idea of how complex this is have a read of this.
I interviewed members of the test and validation teams to gain an understanding of the common workflows and any pain points experienced.
Some of the pain points associated with this process include:
Complexity:

ACLs can be very complex, with a large number of rules and criteria that need to be specified. This can make it difficult to ensure that the ACLs are correctly configured and to troubleshoot issues that arise.
Limited visibility:

In a CLI environment, it can be difficult to get a clear picture of the current ACL configuration or to identify which rules are causing problems. This can make it harder to manage ACLs and ensure that they are functioning correctly.
Time-consuming:
Configuring ACLs in a CLI environment is a time-consuming process that requires a lot of manual input. This can be especially challenging in large networks with complex ACL requirements.
Error-prone:

Configuring ACLs in a CLI environment can be prone to errors, particularly when there are multiple administrators or if the administrator is not experienced or familiar with the syntax and commands involved. It is These errors can lead to security breaches or other issues with network performance.
Lack of automation:

In a CLI environment, ACL configuration is typically a manual process that requires a lot of repetitive tasks. This lack of automation can make it difficult to scale ACL configuration or to make changes quickly in response to changing network requirements.

When users connect to a network, they are assigned an IP address based on the subnet they are connecting from. By using this information, network administrators can assign users to a RADIUS group and then apply access control lists (ACLs) to control their access to network resources.

By assigning users to RADIUS groups based on the subnet they are connecting from, network administrators can apply ACLs more efficiently and control access to network resources more granularly. This approach can be especially useful in large networks with multiple subnets, where it may be necessary to apply different access policies to different groups of users based on their location.

Here's an example of how users who access the network via a specific subnet can be assigned to a RADIUS group to be assigned ACLs:
First, the network administrator would identify the subnet from which the users will be connecting. This could be a physical subnet or a virtual subnet defined by network policies.
Next, the administrator would create a RADIUS group for the users connecting from this subnet. For example, the administrator might create a group called "SubnetA" for users connecting from subnet A.

The administrator would then create ACLs that control access to the network resources based on the requirements of the users in the "SubnetA" group. For example, the administrator might create an ACL that allows users in the "SubnetA" group to access specific servers or applications but blocks access for all other users.
When a user from subnet A tries to access a network resource, the RADIUS server checks the user's credentials and determines that the user is a member of the "SubnetA" group.
The RADIUS server then sends a message to the network device with the appropriate ACL to allow or block access to the resource.

Allowing the user to define rules once and apply them at multiple touchpoints reduces repetition. GUIs can simplify the process of configuring ACLs by reducing the complexity of the configuration process, and presenting the user with simple and intuitive interfaces for defining the rules.
Why do we need to group devices?

Applying ACLs to a grouping of devices can improve the manageability, scalability, and consistency of access control in a network, making it easier to ensure that business requirements are met and that network performance is optimized. As most networks contain sets of devices with similar features it is much faster to define the configuration to a group rather than each device repetitively.
How are groups defined?

Each group should describe a location or role with similar configuration requirements.
For example, The group 'Engineers' could contain all workstations for developers in the engineering department.
 
To support existing networks it was decided that we would automate the creation of groups within Vista Manager for the MVP.  In a later release, we would allow users to create Networks from scratch.
What happens when a new device joins the network?
When new devices are provisioned they will automatically join the corresponding network. If policies have been assigned to the network then ACLS will be generated on the device.
Scenario

An administrator wishes to configure policy which restricts communication between users in the accounts department and the local datacenter. Specifically they wish to block management access to devices in the local data center while permitting all other traffic. TO do this

To resize an image in GIMP, navigate to Image > Scale Image. Within the menu, input the numerical values that you'd like to resize your image by in terms of ...
Lo-fi Miro wireframes were developed during initial team discussions. Initially, the team had suggested using a drag-and-drop to move applications from built-in to custom.

Using Drag and drop to move apps between Predefined and Custom would become difficult when moving apps from a scrolled position outside of the viewport. To solve this we made use of ag-grid custom row features to separate application groups. Each application group is separated by a header row. As DPI apps range in their thousands and cannot be changed we chose to hide these to save space and make the priority changes more obvious to the user.
An introduction slide describing why we want to build applications using components.

To improve the handoff process we updated component names in Figma to match 1:1 with those in Angular e.g. app-my-component-name.  This convention helps us to separate components in the library from feature components when viewing Figma documents or ANgular code.
An example of Angular component inputs mapping to Figma Variants. The component app-message uses the input or variant 'type' to control the background color and icon used in the component.
In this example, you can see Style dictionary 'tokens' in action. Variables are defined in Figma and exported as an npm package for use in angular as an SCSS variable or JS const.
A before and after example showing a CSS class-based template replaced with a generic component.

An example of generic components used in a new feature. Note that we are using flex and utility classes to define high-level layout only. All other styling and state logic comes baked into the components.
An example of uncontrolled traffic. High-priority voice packets are dropped when traveling from a high-capacity link to low capacity link.

An example of controlled traffic. Here traffic is classified so that only non-priority packets are dropped, additionally, traffic entering the network is limited to 128kbps to avoid overloading links.

The default bandwidth percentage (33%) set o each class led users to believe that priority classes should total to 100% of available bandwidth. Any configuration that guarantees 100% of bandwidth would lead to unnecessary traffic loss. Ideally, a maximum of 40% of link capacity should be guaranteed.  We would need to revise the UI to provide useful defaults and better explain the role of guaranteed bandwidth within a policy.
Auto Traffic Shaping (ATS) allocates virtual bandwidth to spokes of multipoint tunnels based on a range of conditions. Bandwidth already guaranteed via Application Priority cannot be used by ATS.
